Fields.DialogueText: Enemy spotted!
I have full faith in you, Captain!
Likewise!
@BATTLE
Well, I'm glad that battle's over...
As am I. I have far better ways I could be spending my time than fighting these beasts.
Where were you, though? I didn't really see you much around the bridge during the skirmish.
I mean, I was fighting! I'm the Belle, after all. It's what I do - I protect the ship! Why wouldn't I be fighting?!

Fields.MenuText: I never said you weren't. I just must've had tunnel vision or something.
I think the lady doth protest too much.
You tell me. Where were you during the fight?

Fields.DialogueText: That must've been it. Don't worry, I won't hold a grudge. Let's just forget this ever happened.
I'm not protesting at all, I'm refuting. Your claims are ridiculous.
I was right there, in the midst of everything! In the... you know, the general... fighting area.
Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some business to attend to. Elsewhere.
Hmmm... I would've seen her, right? She's a little difficult to miss.
Hello there, Mary. How are you?
Calling me by my name and no title. How familiar do you think us to be, Captain?
Do you really mind?
I suppose, as long as it's just the two of us, then there's no harm. But around the crew, and especially if we were to have guests on board, I would expect you to use my full name.
I'm sure that can be arranged. Now - back to my original question. How are you?
I am well. Wonderful weather we're having today.
You have a tendency to do that, you know.
Whatever do you mean?
You have this way of being distant when I'm trying to talk to you.
Excuse me? What do you mean, distant?

Fields.MenuText: You hardly look at me when we're talking.
Look, I hardly know anything about you. I was just hoping to get to know you better.
I don't know... just... distant.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I apologise for that. I'll make sure to look at you directly from now on, Captain.
I'm not all that interesting, if I do say so myself. I'm sure you wouldn't enjoy yourself.
Would you like me to step closer to you when we talk? That way, it would feel more intimate, perhaps?
I just want to have more meaningful conversations with you, Mary. You're the Belle and I'm the captain. We need to learn to trust one another.
Hmmm... I suppose that much is true. It may be difficult for me, but I'll do my best to... open up with you.
I'm glad to hear it. For now, we have other things to attend to.
@BATTLE
Visibility's still not ideal, I see.
You have a gift for understatement.
You're not pleased, I take it.
Oh, I loathe the fog - it's absolutely dreadful.
Don't you agree, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Actually, I enjoy the fog. It has a nice ambience.
I do. Fog just gets in the way. It makes my job more difficult.
At least it's not a storm. I just can't stand thunder.

Fields.DialogueText: Ambience? So you like feeling like you're in some gothic novel? In which you can run with all your might and still not move an inch? Horrible.
Exactly. It's nothing but a nuisance. An extra hurdle for us to jump over.
Why can't the skies just stay shimmering blue while I'm sailing them? I would so appreciate it.
If this ridiculous fog would take a hint and roll away, we'd be able to move so much faster.
It's really slowing you down that much?
Not that much, but we can't reach top speeds, and that's what matters, Captain.
*ALARM*
If you ask me, fighting Morganas matters a little more.
Lovely, just lovely. If this fog wasn't weighing us down, we could just run from this fight altogether.
Why run when we can fight?
You ask the most asinine questions sometimes, you know that, right? Remember, you're speaking to an ocean liner, not a warship.
@BATTLE
Mary, what are you doing? What's with that chart?
I'm double-checking the ship. I want to make sure everything is ship-shape, as it were.
Mary, these aren't guests. They're troops. They won't mind if the floors aren't dusted.
First, floors are mopped, not dusted. Surely you know that much, I hope.
Yes, but-
Second, guests are guests. It's important to make a good first impression.

Fields.MenuText: I guess you have a point.
First impressions, sh-mirst sh-impressions.
So the second impression doesn't matter if the first is good?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you can see that. It's nice to know my captain isn't too thick in the skull.
Mmmm... if you want to make a valid argument, I suggest you start with legitimate English. Not made up words.
I didn't say that. I just said the first is important. All impressions have varying levels of importance.
So how is the ship looking?
Surprisingly, we're looking neat. Of course, we're no competition to my appearance prior to the removal of my furniture, paintings, carpets, and other decorations...
This is war, Mary.
I know, I know, I know. But yes, we should be ready for our charges when we reach port.
Good to hear.
*ALARM*
Sigh... and that is not.
@BATTLE
We're picking up more troops than I expected. I mean, the number is correct, but seeing all of them in person is something else.
I know what you mean, They're like an army of ants... human sized ants.
Are you sure we have room for everyone?
Under normal circumstances, we wouldn't, but we should have more than enough beds now.

Fields.MenuText: What are normal circumstances?
Good. I'd hate to make any of these soldiers sleep on the floor.
And if not, we can always make them pair up and cuddle.

Fields.DialogueText: I was referring to before you military folks went and filled all of my lavish rooms with bunks. I'm still nursing a grudge about that, by the way.
I'm sure they wouldn't mind. After all, they'll be reaching their destinations before they know it.
Now isn't that an interesting idea, Captain. You're a little diabolical, you know that?
*ALARM*
Great, looks like we'll have to stop the boarding for now. Think we'll have any luck stopping this horde?
It's a horde of military men. You're their commanding officer. I'm sure you'll have no issue getting them to follow your orders.
@BATTLE
I didn't do it personally. This is for the war effort.
I know. And I'm happy to help, but it's not excuse for bad taste.
Mary, are you okay? You look deep in thought or something.
I'm just... I'm thinking about my service staff... their living situations with the rest of the troops on board.
Your service staff is still on board?
Some of them. Most of them actually. Chefs, janitors, engineers; many of them stayed with me when I was converted into a military troop transport.
They must be pretty loyal to you, then.
They're like family. But now with all these troops on board, I'm worried they won't be as comfortable as they should be.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure they'll be fine. They knew this was coming.
Why wouldn't they be comfortable? It's a big ship. It's not that crowded.
Comfort is not your top priority anymore. This isn't a pleasure cruise.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you're right. It's not like this was a huge surprise.
You and I seem to have different definitions of the word ''crowded,'' Captain. This room is too crowded for me right now.
Comfort is always important. It's why passengers would return to me time and again, why they would trust me. Because a trip on the Queen Mary is a pleasurable experience.
Our charges are only going to grow in number. I need to think more about how to keep my service staff comfortable amongst all the troops. Please leave.
Okay, I'll give you your space. Keep an ear out for the alarm, though. We'll need your help if we run into any Morganas.
Yes, yes, Morganas. I heard you. Just leave.
@BATTLE
You and I are the only ones in here.
Exactly.
Mary?! Has anyone seen Mary?
Oh, I believe I saw her swimming around the ship. She's practically a dolphin.
She's swimming around the ship?!
Correction, I WAS swimming around the ship. I can't let the ship get in better shape than myself.

Fields.MenuText: Are you kidding? You look great.
I guess you do have a point. I do often compare you to the ship.
I'd say you need to try a little harder. You're looking a little plump.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, thank you, you flatterer. Though don't start leering now, Captain.
I--wait... Did you just call me fat?
Hmph! You're one to talk. Maybe you should think about joining me for a few laps, Captain.
*ALARM*
Looks like I got out of my swimsuit just in time.
One workout after another, huh?
These fights do get my heart racing.
@BATTLE
Uh, no?
Captain, these brutish troops of yours are entirely uncultured!
First of all, they're not my troops, and secondly, that came out of nowhere. What happened?
A pack of them just came up to me and complained about my armaments!
They said I didn't have enough "boom!" Who would say a thing like that to a Belle?!

Fields.MenuText: Well, they have a point. Your weapons do leave something to be desired.
That is a little out of line. They should be more polite to their hostess.
There are a lot of troops out there who aren't afraid to speak their mind.

Fields.DialogueText: How can you side with them, Captain?! Whether or not they're correct isn't the important part!
Exactly. They should be thankful for any weapons. If I had my way, we'd be weaponless!
That doesn't make it right!
My firepower may not be significant, but I more than make up for it in speed.
Trust me, I know. You don't see me complaining, do you?
I'm just no fan of your soldiers, Captain. Would you teach them some manners?
They aren't my soldiers.
They might as well be.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
We've got Morganas headed this direction! Get ready for a fight, Mary.
Do we need to fight? Wouldn't it be easier to run?
What are you talking about?
Well, my strength is speed, not power. Wouldn't it be more intelligent to use my strength?

Fields.MenuText: Hmmm, I suppose that might not be the worst idea.
If we don't fight them, who will?
Don't be so skittish, Mary.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. I mean, we have places to go and people to see after all.
Some other Belle, maybe? I don't know. Not every Morgana is our responsibility.
I don't know what you're talking about. I'm not afraid. I'm sure, if I were to fight these brutes, I would have no trouble putting them down.
*BOOM*
Well, it doesn't look like running is an option anymore.
Running is always an option. Especially when you're as fast as I am.
Why are you so intent on speeding away?
... I'm not... Ugh! Let's just get this over with!
@BATTLE
Mary? What are you doing up here?
Just remembering the good old times. The golden years...
This used to be a rather fancy dining room, right?
It used to be gorgeous. We had extraordinary events with food and drink, glamorous guests, and lovely decorations.
... I wish you could've seen it.

Fields.MenuText: It sounds like one hell of a party.
If you ask me, it still looks pretty nice up here.
Sounds a little hoity-toity to me. I prefer a nice barbecue.

Fields.DialogueText: That's one way to put it. I think you would've enjoyed it.
Oh, please. All traces of elegance have been stripped away or covered in this garish leather.
A barbecue, you say? Well, I'm not sure you'd have enjoyed my kinds of ballroom galas.
Don't mind me, Captain. I'm just feeling a little nostalgic for the days before the war.
Well, the war won't last forever, Mary. And with your help, we should be able to end it a little sooner.
That's a nice thought.
*ALARM*
And just in time, Morganas come to ruin the day.
They haven't ruined anything yet, so let's make sure they don't!
@BATTLE
Mary, are you okay?
Hm?
You're glaring again.
What are you talking about? I'm fine. And I don't glare!

Fields.MenuText: You've been glaring off and on since the troops came on board.
My apologies, I must've been mistaken. That just must be your normal face.
Everybody glares. It's what people do when they're pissed off.

Fields.DialogueText: This isn't glaring. It's just a look of indignation.
Yes. You were mistaken. I'm completely fine. I'm happy, even.
Well, I'm not people. I'm a Belle. Maybe Belles don't glare. How would you know?
Mary, you can keep pretending you're fine if you prefer, but I think it would be beneficial if you would tell me what's troubling you.
I'm not...
I'd rather you not lie to me.
... I just like my space. I miss it. It's getting a little crowded for me.
I understand that. And I'll see about finding you some space... somewhere on board. But, look on the bright side - thanks to your speed, we've nearly reached our destination.
I... suppose that's somewhat reassuring.
Now that's the smile I wanted to see.
What are you talking about? I was already smiling. I always smile.
*ALARM*
Except when that alarm goes off.
Ugh. You're right about that.
@BATTLE
Mary, is that a bouquet of flowers?
I promise they're not imitations, Captain.
I can see that. How did you...?
One of my service staff picked them up for me. She said she wanted to brighten my day. I absolutely love fresh flowers. Want a sniff?

Fields.MenuText: No, thank you. I'm not a big flower person.
Mmmm. Those do smell nice. We should get them in water.
Just a sniff? You have a whole bouquet - you can't give me just one flower?

Fields.DialogueText: Who doesn't like flowers? I'm beginning to think there may be something wrong with you, hmph!
You're right. I'd like these beauties to last as long as possible.
Well, if I gave you one, then I wouldn't have a bouquet anymore. Their true beauty is only revealed when they're all together.
So are those your favorite flowers? Should I keep them in mind next time i'm buying you a gift?
All flowers are beautiful. I'm not sure I have a favorite.
*ALARM*
Ugh. I know I have a least favorite, though.
I'm not sure Morganas count as flowers.
They're my least favorite everything.
@BATTLE
Mary, before you look into the mess, I think we should discuss...
What in the name of all that's...!
Damn. Too slow.
What have they done?! Look at the state of this dining hall! It's horrendous!

Fields.MenuText: It's not that bad.
You're right, this is really bad...
Eh, it looks better than my room.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you blind? Or stupid? This will take hours to clean. You'd better be ready to help!
I'm glad you agree. Though, it would be more helpful if you grabbed a mop and helped clean up.
... What's wrong with your room? Do you live in a pile of your own filth like some kind of farm animal?!
You know what? Never mind. Just do something about those unruly troops.
What do you want me to do?
I don't care. But they need an attitude adjustment. Whatever you have to do, do it.
*ALARM*
Uh, that's not great timing. I guess we'll have to clean this up later.
I'm not leaving this dining hall until it's spotless!
What about the Morganas?
I... okay, fine. Lead the way. But we're coming right back here after the battle.
@BATTLE
Captain!
I'm here. What's happening?
Captain, there's some trouble up ahead.
What? I thought we were about to reach our destination.
We are, and that's the trouble. Our destination is being assaulted by Morganas!

Fields.MenuText: That's not what I wanted to hear.
What are we waiting for, then? We should rush to their aid.
How many Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, it's not what I wanted to see. We should maybe think about circling the block a few times.
It's not as if we'd be an immense help. We might be better off keeping out of their business.
Too many. If we head in now, I'm afraid we wouldn't make it through the fight.
Why are you so hesitant to engage Morganas? You're a Belle, it's what you do.
Belles protect their ship and their crew. Rushing headfirst toward death is the opposite of that.
We're not going to die.
You don't know that!
*ALARM*
Well, it sounds like they noticed us. So maybe I'll get the chance to prove it to you. We're not going to die.
I hope you're right, Captain.
@BATTLE
I see you're watching the action.
Hello, Captain.
Look at them all go. Running out of the ship like it's on fire.
I wouldn't be surprised if one of the hooligans actually did set a fire. I'm glad to see them leave.

Fields.MenuText: You don't think they might have actually set a fire, do you?
I'm going to miss them. A few of them were going to start a poker tournament.
You're not the only one. It'll be nice to have the ship back to ourselves.

Fields.DialogueText: No. I was exaggerating, Captain. You don't have to worry about any fires.
Poker? That's your idea of fun? Ack. To each their own, I suppose.
Yes, it's nice to finally be able to breathe easy again. I missed having all this space on board.
You should remember, Mary. We're picking up our next batch of troops for transport soon, so don't get too comfortable.
You don't need to remind me. Trust me, I know. I was just letting myself have a moment of satisfaction, though I suppose that's over now.
Hey, now - we don't have to pick them up immediately. We have to resupply, after all.
You know how to make me smile, don't you, Captain?
I try. Though we probably should do a quick patrol of the area to scare off any lingering Morganas.
Aaannd the smile's gone.
@BATTLE
Captain... I was hoping to ask you for a favour.
Depends on what it is.
It's nothing big, really.
I... I just want to redecorate a little.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean redecorate?
I... guess that would be okay. Just don't go overboard.
Redecorate? That's the last thing we need to be doing.

Fields.DialogueText: I just want to spruce the place up a bit. Make it a little like the good old days.
It won't be anything crazy, don't worry. I know what I'm doing, after all.
Think of it as... boosting morale. Morale is important during times of war, right?
All right, I'll give you some leeway to make some changes. Just remember, we still need room for all the troops.
I've already considered that. The decorations I have in mind will be confined to the walls.
That should be fine.
*ALARM*
Great, just when my mood was lifting.
Ah, they must've sensed it.
@BATTLE
Captain? You wanted to see me?
Yes. I'm afraid I've got some bad news, and I wanted to make sure you heard it from me.
If it's about how many troops we're picking up, I'm afraid you can't outrace the gossip. I've heard.

Fields.MenuText: It's not that many when you think about it.
I know it's a lot, but we're not taking them too far.
And you're not screaming? That's a surprise.

Fields.DialogueText: I've thought about it, and it's still a lot.
That is a saving grace. We won't have to deal with the crowd for that long.
I don't scream. I'm a lady. The most I do is raise my voice menacingly.
I'm mostly worried about my service staff. I don't want them to feel crushed under the weight of all these troops.
They've been fine so far, haven't they?
Yes, but I'm concerned they're just putting on a strong front for me.
Because that's what you would do?
It's not a front if you truly are strong and sophisticated.
All right, if you're so strong, let's go on patrol and hunt down some Morganas to prove it.
A truly strong person doesn't need to prove their strength.
Well, we're going on patrol anyway, so...
Sigh... Fine, if we must.
@BATTLE
So, this is what you meant by redecorating?
Oh, Captain, I didn't notice you there.
Well, you were a little preoccupied hanging up all these paintings.
What do you think? I think it adds a touch of much needed colour.

Fields.MenuText: I can agree with that.
I'm not really too big on art...
Is there a reason they're all so... flowery?

Fields.DialogueText: It's nice to know you have some taste, Captain.
Really? I suppose that makes sense, considering the state of your office.
You think this is flowery? Ha, this is nothing. You should see my quarters.
How many paintings have you hung up around the ship?
I've finished half the ship... and I stopped counting when I neared the triple digits.
Triple digits? How much has this cost us?
*ALARM*
Oh, look at that, we've got Morganas to fight.
Oh, now you go off running towards a fight? Get back here with an expense report!
@BATTLE
Is that a fashion magazine, Mary?
Oh, this? I had it picked up for me when we were last at port. I always like to keep up with the latest trends.
Oh, interesting... I guess I never took you for the fashion magazine type.
And what is that supposed to mean?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, nothing, I didn't mean anything!
You seem like the kind of person whose reading materials would be a little more literary.
I just don't think much of fashion magazines. Not worth my time.

Fields.DialogueText: Mhmmmm... That's better.
You'd be surprised how many sophisticated people can find worthwhile information in these articles. These magazines are more worldly than you might expect.
Maybe you should give them a chance. You might grow to like them. You could even learn a thing or two.
You know, Captain. I think it might be fun to give you a little makeover.
You want to give me a makeover?
What do you say?
*ALARM*
I say we've got more important things to worry about right now.
That's such a you thing to say.
@BATTLE
And here we are again, filling the ship with troops.
I'm already starting to get all itchy. Are the walls starting to close? Could the ship itself be shrinking?
We're on deck.
Not much for metaphor, are you, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Just breathe. Everything will be all right.
Calm down. There's no need to overreact.
Actually... I think the walls are starting to close in on us.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay... breathe in... and out. That's actually helping a little.
You're right. I need to keep my composure. Never let them see you sweat.
I know you're just trying to make me feel better. Thank you, Captain, but I'll be all right. Of that, I'm relatively sure...
Let's just hurry and get everyone on board. The sooner they're all on board, the sooner we can get them off board.
Sounds like a plan. And with you, the trip will fly by. They'll have disembarked before you know it.
You're right. The only things that will slow us down are...
*ALARM*
You were going to say Morganas, weren't you?
Grr... Obviously.
@BATTLE
Looking good, Mary.
And you're as charming as ever, Captain. Thank you.
Did you already clean up the mess hall after lunch?
No... actually... these troops seem to be remarkably well behaved. They didn't leave so much as a scrap of food on the floor.

Fields.MenuText: I don't believe that for a second. They had to have made some kind of mess.
Hmmm... I guess different soldiers have different training.
Is that a good thing or a bad thing?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm as shocked and confused as you are, but they left the dining hall exactly as they found it.
I suppose. And these soldiers seem to have better training in etiquette.
It's a good thing, certainly. Do you think I like to spend my free time cleaning up after children?
I guess this means I'm going to have to start cleaning up after myself as well.
Especially now that I'm bringing some refinement back to the ship. You don't want to seem out of place.
I don't think a few paintings are going to make this ship as grandiose as it used to be.
Just wait and see what I have planned, Captain. You may be surprised.
For now, I'd just be surprised to see you battling a Morgana without putting up an argument first.
I always fight Morganas.
But I know you'd rather run.
Of course. I'm not crazy.
@BATTLE
Mary, I've been meaning to ask you something for a while.
Ask away. I'll try to be an open book.
Why do you care so much about how the ship looks? This is war. As long as we do our jobs, it shouldn't matter how we look, right?
I wasn't built for this war. I was built for pleasure and elegance. I understand that this war is important, but I still believe that how we're perceived matters.
Plus... it does bring me back to the good old days. Don't you ever look back to the way things were?

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes... I do miss the peace.
Those days weren't good for everyone.
I hardly remember them. It seems like so long ago now.

Fields.DialogueText: I think we all do. They were truly better days.
... Yes, I suppose you have a point, there.
I know, but this war will end eventually. And then we'll have those pleasant days back.
If you want those days back so badly, it's all the more reason to focus on fighting rather than fashion.
You make a good point... but I don't see why we can't have both.
*ALARM*
That's one reason why.
Aha! Perhaps the Morganas are angry merely because their outward appearances are so dreadful.
I really don't think that's it...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Eeek! Stupid alarm. So abrupt. We need to... we need to turn that down, or something.
Are you sure it's the alarm that scared you and not the Morganas?
Are you implying something, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Just that Morganas scare the crap out of you.
I just think we all need to face our fears. And I think you fear these Morganas.
I'm not going to push you, Mary. If you're not ready to talk about it, that's fine.

Fields.DialogueText: Eh, language, Captain. I am a lady.
I hardly think I'm alone in my fear.
... And if I am ready to talk... I suppose I should just talk then.
Why wouldn't I find the Morganas fearsome?
Well, why would you?
I don't want to die! I've only just woken up. I don't want that to end so soon...
... Mary, I'd love to say you won't die, but I'm not sure about that. This is war. People die.
But I can say that everyone on board is fighting. They're putting their lives on the line for the good of the world. You should too.
And I can tell you this as well. As long as I'm your captain, I will do my uttermost to protect you.
I... can we get to the deck? That alarm means that Morganas are coming. Is this the best time for a pep talk?
I just need to know that you hear me.
I hear you.
Good. Here's to another fight.
@BATTLE
Captain, I've made a decision. You were right.
I'm going to need a little more information. I'm right about many things.
I can't live in fear of these Morganas. I don't want to die, but a life in fear is... is no life at all!
Okay... that's good.
*ALARM*
I have a bad feeling that that isn't a coincidence is it?
No. No, it isn't.
What did you do, Mary?
I'm fighting my fears head on. We're heading straight into the biggest group of Morganas I could find. And we're going to defeat each and every one of them.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like my kind of plan.
Are you crazy? That sounds needlessly dangerous.
This doesn't sound like you. Who are you and what did you do with my Belle?

Fields.DialogueText: I thought you might like it. Truth be told, I'm still a little nervous about it.
I think that's the point? Look at me, I'm shaking like a leaf in a storm.
It's me, I can assure you. I'm just... I'm trying to approach life from a different perspective.
We should get ready, Captain. We're rapidly approaching our targets.
Okay, but a little more warning next time would be appreciated, Mary.
I sure hope there's going to be a next time.
Hey, no talking like that.
You're right. We're going to win. I'm not going to die here.
@BATTLE
Another enemy inbound! Full speed ahead!
I should technically be giving those orders, you realize.
Oh. Captain, I'm...
No, it's all right. Full speed!
@BATTLE
Oh, hello, Captain. Ahhh... Did you need... *yawn*... something?
No, I just heard from some of the officers that you were... doing some remodeling.
Heh, I wouldn't go that far. I'm just removing this hideous leather they covered my dining hall with! I wanted to take it out of the staterooms too, but that seemed too drastic.
Okay... but why are you doing this?
That's a surprise.

Fields.MenuText: Mary, tell me now. That's an order.
Hmm, I like surprises. I just hope it's a good one.

Fields.DialogueText: You'd order me to ruin a surprise? That's horrible, Captain.
Oh, it's a great one! If everything goes as planned, it'll be amazing.
I'll give you one little hint: It's going to be absolutely glamorous.
That's the worst hint I've ever heard.
*ALARM*
Well, I suppose I'll have to tear the rest of this dastardly leather off later.
Do you really need to?
Have you seen it? It's beyond hideous. It's almost as bad as that gray paint job they gave my hull!
I kind of like the gray.
Oh, hush.

Fields.MenuText: Ha! Always preoccupied with the strangest things, that one.
She's... altogether too much fun to tease.
